Rising to the challenge: A systematic review of the development of environmental justice in India
Ubaid Sidique and Khurram Zaidi
Department of Political Science, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, India
ABSTRACT

Environmental justice has experienced rapid expansion in its scope and conceptualization in the last three decades. Literature on environmental justice narrates how individuals and communities mobilize to confront economic and environmental issues at the local, national, and global levels and how globalization, gender, racism, and class affect the environment. This article presents a systematic review of environmental justice in India, aimed at showing how the concept originated and came into common parlance and how it differs or actually resembles now a lot with the environmental justice discourse in the United States. The focus of this study is on various salient events that are crucial in the development of a well-established movement. The review contends that environmental justice may have only recently become a recognized concept in Indian environmental history, as a philosophy, it has been a mainstay of Indian environmental consciousness. India has an indigenous environmental justice movement, albeit not on the lines of the US. This review also suggests that the discourse on environmental justice in India is currently shaped by both global environmental justice movements as well as indigenous efforts and concerns about environmental challenges.
Introduction

Environmental justice (EJ) as a concept initially developed in the United States (US) in the early 1980s, as a result of the campaign against racial inequality<sup>1</sup> with respect to the unjust burden of pollution. EJ activism has been an integral component of the politics of communities of color since the 1800s, with people attempting to better their housing conditions and resisting unfair legislation.<sup>2</sup> It highlights the Ecological Distribution Conflicts which refer to societal disputes caused by uneven access to natural resources and unfair distribution of pollution loads.<sup>3</sup>

This paper aims to present an in-depth discussion on the genesis and evolution of EJ scholarship in India. The focus is on various salient events that were crucial in the development of a well-established movement and an academic discourse that we currently refer to as environmental justice. The paper further looks at the various aspects in which the EJ movement in the US is different from the one in India. The first
INDIA REVIEW
ROUTEDGE
Routledge
Taylor & Francis Group
2024 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC

part of this article briefly describes how the term "environmental justice" first appeared and then entered into common usage in the United States. There are many exceptional accounts on the origin and evolution of the Environmental Justice Movement (EJM) in the US. The purpose of this article is not to duplicate such studies, but rather to provide the solid foundation and outline for the comparative study of environmental justice in India.

The second part of this study delineates through India's rich environmental past and shows the development of EJ discourse in India through the three waves of environmentalism<sup>4</sup> used to describe the history of India's environmental consciousness. By outlining the circumstances and issues surrounding this movement, this paper concludes by examining how the idea of EJ developed and spread beyond the US and if there is any influence of the EJM of the US on the development of EJ discourse in India.
Defining environmental justice

The earliest accounts of environmental justice advocacy and research surfaced under the framework of "environmental racism," a term introduced by Benjamin F. Chavis during the 1982 Warren County demonstrations. According to him;

Environmental racism is racial discrimination in environmental policymaking, in the enforcement of regulations and laws and in the deliberate targeting of communities of color for toxic waste sitting. It is racial discrimination in the official sanctioning of the life-threatening presence of poisons and pollutants in communities of color and the history of excluding people of color from the mainstream environmental groups, decision-making boards, commissions, and regulatory bodies.[5]

This frame focused on waste facility siting and its link to race and poverty<sup>6</sup> and documented cases where race affected negative environmental externalities.<sup>7</sup> In the early 1990s EJ studies shifted from a particular and radical "environmental racism" framing to a more broad and less radical "environmental injustice" frame.<sup>8</sup> This framework, like environmental racism, had negative and reactive connotations and gave only a prognosis, leaving the underlying issue untreated. Over time, environmental injustice grew less popular and was replaced with "environmental justice," which has a more positive and proactive tone. The EJ frame extended beyond racism to encompass gender, age, and income in evaluating unfair burdens on specific populations.<sup>9</sup> It seeks to rectify the previous injustices against specific communities in the US by taking corrective actions.<sup>10</sup> Environmental justice is the most appropriate and inclusive framework for addressing environmental injustices,<sup>11</sup> given the myriad ways in which it can manifest. It is so flexible and inclusive that it became a "master frame."<sup>12</sup>
U.SIDIQUE AND K.ZAIDI

The term "environmental justice" is highly contested in its conceptualization and definitions.<sup>13</sup> Multiple manifestations of the concept have led to diverse narratives depending on the purposes of the study. One of the most acclaimed definitions of environmental justice has come from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), of the US, which defines it as;

The fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people regardless of race, ethnicity, income, national origin, or educational level with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations and policies. Fair treatment means that no population, due to policy or economic disempowerment, is forced to bear a disproportionate burden of the negative human health or environmental impacts of pollution or other environmental consequences resulting from industrial, municipal, and commercial operations or the execution of federal, state, local, and tribal programs and policies.[14]

The EJ research seeks to rethink what the term "environment" means, going beyond a "nature-centred ecology" toward a "human-centred ecology" that considers the social and built environments.[15] Specifically, the EJ discourse reframes environmental challenges as public health and quality of life concerns rather than the previous notions of the environment that primarily focused on natural resource protection.[16] It considers preservation of nature and environmental aesthetics important but highly overemphasized ambitions, described in the literature as "bourgeois obsessions."[17] Environmental justice is firmly entrenched in the "brown" agenda of environmentalism, which is centered on alleviating conditions to meet basic human needs, especially health and well-being.[18]
Historical overview of environmental justice in the US

The environmental movements in the US have their genesis in the nineteenth century, prior to which concern about the environment was rare. Instead, the biblical injunction to go forth and conquer the earth was the dominant ideology.[19] This belief is articulated in terms of the Exploitative Capital Paradigm[20] which saw resources to be plentiful and renewable. Environmental degradation was perceived as an inevitable result of economic progress and development. People finally realized about earths limited resources after the westward movement of the original colonies ended.[21] Original colonies alludes to the 13 British colonies in North America, where evicted farmers, religious dissidents, and African slaves settled. This sparked the first environmental movement in the U.S.

Dowie categorizes US EJ history into three periods.[22] The first period is of the nineteenth century, which was primarily concerned with conservation and preservation. Characterized by the Romantic Environmental Paradigm (REP), which decried the degradation of resources and urged people to live in peace with nature,[23] focus was on conserving nature and its resources from
INDIA REVIEW
overexploitation during the industrial revolution. The principles of EJ as it is today conceptualized and recognized were lacking from environmental discourse.

The second wave emerged with the rise of mainstream environmentalism in the 1960s. This period saw a shift in how environmental, social, and health concerns were seen. It sparked considerable public concern for environmental deterioration and a cleaner environment. Equal priority was given to human health, the environment, and other living species. While some consider Earth Day in 1970 as the starting point, others argue that Rachel Carson's Silent Spring is a more suitable beginning for mainstream environmentalism. The New Environmental Paradigm (NEP) ushered in as a new perspective at this time.[24] After this shift, environmentalism evolved into "resource conservation, wilderness preservation, public health reform, population control, ecology, energy conservation, anti-pollution regulation, and occupational health campaigns."[25] This changed the American understanding of "environment" from admiring nature to tackling water and air pollution, waste management, and land use.

The third phase spans the early 1980s to the late 1990s, when concerns about social justice, civil liberties, and environmental conservation began to converge. During this period, responses to unfavorable environmental forces predominated, while the economy received more attention. This time witnessed significant local mobilization and grassroots organizations opposing the unequal distribution of landfills, incinerators, and other hazardous waste facilities.[26] It led to increased engagement of disadvantaged people in environmental decision-making and a renewed government commitment to preserve justice via environmental laws and regulations. Neither of these qualities was prevalent during the first or early stages of the second wave of American environmentalism. Studies indicate that the grassroots anti-toxic campaign gained national prominence only during the third wave. The decisive moment in the evolution of the "anti-toxics movement" to EJM was in 1982, when a polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB)-contaminated landfill was placed in a small, prominent black neighborhood in Warren County, North Carolina.[27]

This phase mostly highlighted the siting of hazardous waste facilities, incinerators, and other polluting sources in close proximity to the disadvantaged sections of society, who were mainly poor or nonwhite.[28] In light of these academic and activist endeavors, the First National People of Color Environmental Leadership Summit (FNPCELS) was held in Washington, D. C. in 1991. The summit stands out as the most crucial event in the history of EJ. It adopted the Seventeen Principles of Environmental Justice, which serve as the foundation for EJ research today and symbolize the movement's future objectives.[29] These principles reveal a well-developed ideological framework, articulated in the Environmental Justice Paradigm (EJP), that explicitly links ecological concerns with race, class, gender and social justice.[30]
U. SIDIQUE AND K. ZAIDI

By the turn of the twentieth century, a fourth wave of American environmentalism was anticipated. While minimizing disagreements and adopting important components of the previous three stages, the fourth wave established its own traits.[31] This period saw the concept's geographic expansion. With substantial prior research in the US, EJ mobilization and discourses have extended and been reframed globally. The EJ frame was initially used outside the US in the mid-1900s, but it spread widely after the turn of the century.[32] The most important breakthrough in environmental justice outside the US was the Aarhus Convention of 1998. It is the most significant regional development in environmental public participation and environmental justice, empowering people to seek justice by participating in environmental decision-making.[33] While expanding geographically from local to global, EJ also expanded its scope with the term "global" not limited to an extended geographical sphere but also to an extended socio-economic and political sphere.[34] Central to this wave is the notion of "sustainability"[35] which has been better defined by the Brundtland Commission report as "development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs."[36] The report also stipulates that "concern for social equity between generations ... must logically be extended to equity within generations."[37] Therefore, it is logically impossible to distinguish the environmental rights of future generations from those currently belonging to other nationalities, or other classes, or races within the same nation[38] and who are incapable of effectively advocating their interests for geographic, socioeconomic and political reasons.[39] Thus, while upholding the rights of future generations (intergenerational equity), we are obliged to evaluate the ethical acceptability of the distribution of economic and environmental costs and benefits among existing people and communities, i.e., intra-generational equity.[40]

The EJM in the US represents the coming together of two well-established movements, i.e., the Environmental Movement and the Civil Rights Movement. The convergence of these movements and how they helped build EJM is well documented<sup>41</sup> and is beyond the scope of this article. This paper will now look at the history of EJ in India and how it differs or actually resembles now a lot with the movement in the US.
Environmental justice in India

Environmental justice, as defined in the peer-reviewed literature, is relatively new in India. However, India has a rich heritage of environmentalism, most of which has been about social justice.[42] Environmentalism in India has an old history, with the Vedic seers glorifying the nature-human relationship unparalleled to any other such traditions.[43] Environmental philosophy has always been present in Indian history. From the environmental consciousness
INDIA REVIEW
emanating from the Vedas and Upanishads to the modern environmental movements, India has seen rich religious, social and cultural heritage of environmentalism and environmental justice.

According to Ramachandra Guha, Indian environmentalism has evolved in two waves: an early period of pioneering and prophecy, and a more modern one in which intellectual contemplation is paired with popular social movements.[44] The first wave, in the early twentieth century, reiterated the philosophy of "deep ecology," which encourages valuing nature for its intrinsic worth rather than its utility.[45] In the 1970s, India witnessed the rise of a second wave in the form of localized social movements. This current focused not just on trees and tigers but also on environmental advantages and costs of common people.[46] Since 1991, after India opened its economy, the environmental situation has been gloomy. The effect on both the environment and its people has prompted a new public consciousness and a third wave of environmentalism evolved. Thus, any examination of Indian environmental justice discourse should start with its genesis and development.
First wave: era of intellectual pioneers

The first phase of environmentalism in India spanned from the early twentieth century to the outbreak of the second world war.[47] The emphasis here was mainly on the pattern of economic development India should embrace after its independence. According to Guha, environmental issues were not unknown in the past, the industrial revolution escalated them into an environmental crisis.[48] Thus, environmentalism per se is a recent construct that sprang out as a reaction to the industrial revolution. It enlarged our sense of rights and justice, encouraging us to respect nature's rights and live sustainably.

This period was dominated by a brand of intellectual pioneers, who relied on moral and cultural perspectives in disapproving the modern way of life. Often cited in the academic literature as "Crusading Gandhians"49 since their environmentalism staunchly emulates the Gandhian philosophy. They consider environmental crisis as a moral issue rooted in materialism and consumerism, which fosters wasteful lifestyles and draws humans away from nature.50 This period focused on the unsustainable nature of the western economic development model. Intellectuals of this era showed how the western style of development exploits "man by man and nature by man."51 Gandhi himself in "The Hind Swaraj" precisely disapproved of the western political and economic systems. He was critical of India going for industrialization after the manner of the west on moral grounds, but his reservations also had ecological undertones.52 Although environmental movements gained steam in the post-Gandhian era, he foresaw the dangers of the unsustainable development path the world marched on. His understanding of the macroeconomic development processes offers insightful explanations for the environmental
U.SIDIQUE AND K.ZAIDI

crisis. Other pioneers, like J. C. Kumarappa, Mira Behn (Madeline Slade), and M Krishnan, among others, further developed and advanced this economic philosophy that promoted an alternative, non-modern, Indian-rooted worldview.[53] Their rural romanticism, reflected in their call to return to pre-colonial or pre-capitalist village society, led them to exclusively emphasize agrarian environmental problems, reinforced with hostility toward modern industry.[54]

This period predominantly focused on the conservation and the preservation of nature and its resources from overexploitation. However, with the outbreak of the Second World War, the first wave's "green agenda" had few takers. After independence, the first priority was to meet the economic needs of its people. Rapid industrialization on western lines was thought to eradicate poverty and unemployment and produce a strong, self-reliant community.[55] Environmental concern was overlooked as India marched toward industrial development. Only in the 1970s did India see a new wave of environmentalism in the shape of focused social movements.
Second wave: popular social movements

India, after independence, aspired to industrialize rapidly. The decision-makers called for resource-intensive and capital-intensive economic planning, such that the 1950s and 1960s were branded as "development decades."[56] During this period, environment and sustainability were anathema to economic growth and were considered as tactics of the west to obstruct the development of post-colonial states.[57] With a goal of lifting millions out of poverty, this period was described as the "age of ecological innocence."[58] By the early 1970s, state-sponsored industrialization failed to spur economic development. Poverty persisted and only a few wealthy urbanites and rural landlords benefited from the development. On the other hand, the environment suffered excessive degradation, with natural resources diminishing at an alarming rate, pauperizing millions of people.[59]

By this time, environmentalism was being aggressively articulated in the developed countries, and the developing countries were compelled to respond by formulating their own policies.[60] As the consequences of the decisions made after 1947 became apparent, environmental concerns steadily reemerged in public debate. Predominantly, after the 1972 Stockholm Conference, a stronger and a new consciousness of environmental issues emerged across the world, including India.[61] The environmentalism of this period was not merely an intellectual critique but the rise of popular social movements, with country-wide reach and addressing ecological and socio-economic problems. The rise of social movements, referred to as the "environmentalism of the poor,"[62] has played a significant role in the development of EJM in India. These movements raised awareness of environmental issues, put pressure on
INDIA REVIEW
the government and corporations to act, and ensured that the needs and rights of local communities are considered in the development of infrastructure projects and other initiatives.

The watershed movement with which the ecological question made a dramatic reentry in Indian national life was the Chipko Movement (Hug-The-Trees) in 1973, highlighting a range of conflicts over natural resource use that sprang up across India in the 1970s and 1980s. After Chipko, the Narmada Bachao Andolan (Save the Narmada movement) and Kerala fisherfolk raised awareness of the significance of fish and water use.[63] Also, there were protests against mineral extraction, land and industrial conflicts across the country. These demonstrations rejected the claim that India couldn't be environmentally responsible.[64] During this phase, environmental issues were taken up with more vigor by grassroots movements. They prompted social and natural scientists to pursue environmental research, leading to the emergence of "environmental history" and "environmental sociology."[65] The scientific studies and the environmental reporting highlighted damages to human health and wellbeing, revealing social consequences of environmental abuse. According to Ramachandra Guha, grassroots protests, not library books or university courses, exposed scholars to the environmental crisis.[66] The 1984 Bhopal Gas Disaster can be marked the beginning of the environmental justice movement in India. An explosion at a pesticide facility at Union Carbide India Limited in Bhopal killed over 20,000 people, with 15,342 people actually provided compensation under death category[67] and maiming nearly half a million more, including their descendants.[68] The Bhopal disaster was undeniably a reflection of the issues concerning environmental justice and political economy that drew attention to the potential negative effects of environmental contamination on people and their communities.[69]

The environmentalists of this time, however, inflated the concerns. To make their influence known and dictate national policy, they "talked in alarmist and even apocalyptic language, forecasting death, diseases, the loss of national sovereignty, and the destruction of Indian culture."[70] This, together with the collapse of the Berlin Wall and India's LPG (Liberalisation, Privatisation and Globalisation) reforms in 1991, provoked a huge anti-environmental reaction. In the backdrop of these developments, we witnessed the beginning of the third wave.
Third wave: the environment and the social justice

After the fall of the erstwhile USSR, the viability of the American development model became inevitable.[71] India, not holding back, went for economic liberalization, in which the state started retreating, and private enterprises became more involved in planning. During this time, environmentalists faced tremendous backlash. The environmental constraints were disregarded, and
U. SIDIQUE AND K. ZAIDI
environmental activists were vilified as anti-development brigade and a major roadblock in the smooth Americanisation of Indian society.72

By the turn of the twentieth century, it was apparent that India's economic decisions had a detrimental effect on the environment and, as a result, on the lives and livelihoods of its citizens.[73] Air, water, soil, and food are all severely contaminated throughout India, turning India into an "environmental basket case."[74] The unprecedented loss of natural resources and biodiversity is affecting the lives and livelihoods of those who rely on it. Development projects are approved without an environmental and socioeconomic impact assessment.[75] Poor environmental compliance in current development projects disadvantages individuals in such zones. Extreme weather, including floods, heatwaves and droughts, has become the norm. Due to excessive traffic, rising pollution, and new disease-spreading vectors, most Indian cities are in a public health crisis. Even in other fields, such as waste management, public health, human resource development, and climate change, the situation is bleak. Natural as well as development-induced displacements are increasing, with a small percentage of resettlement.[76] All these issues have a social justice dimension since negative ecological changes exacerbate poverty by disproportionately affecting the poor who depend heavily on ecosystem services.[77] Research has also revealed that India's laws, policies, and governance are grossly inadequate and unprepared to address sustainability and justice issues.[78]

The environmental rhetoric of the new millennium that interlinks environmental issues with social justice problems defines this third wave. It focuses less on appreciation of nature than on environmental problems that endanger impoverished people and their livelihoods. As a result, while addressing environmental concerns, emphasis has been more often on the issues of social justice.[79] This current phase is also witnessing expansion in the conceptualization of environmental justice away from the western juridical frameworks. The Indian judiciary has played a pivotal role in this direction, which will be succinctly touched on in the following section.
Environmental justice and the Indian judiciary

The original Indian constitution didn't specify environmental justice, environmental rights, or environmental conservation and preservation. The preamble acknowledges social, economic, and political justice, but not ecological or environmental justice. This non-inclusion could be for two main reasons: First, at that time, although people were aware of the environmental problems, it was not seen as a major crisis. Second, the framers of the constitution had probably not anticipated the environmental mayhem that the country is facing now.
Nevertheless, India made substantial progress by enacting critical environmental laws, programs, and policies to safeguard its environment.[80] Following
INDIA REVIEW

its commitments at the 1972 Stockholm conference to balance development and environmental protection, India amended its constitution and introduced progressive laws and regulation.[81] The notable development was the Constitution (Forty-second amendment) Act, 1976, which incorporated two main environmental provisions under Article 48(A) and Article 51A(g). While Article 48(A) mandates the government to safeguard the nation's forests and wildlife, Article 51A(g) encourages every citizen to do the same and show compassion for all living things. These obligations on the state and the citizens lead the judiciary to employ constitutional mechanisms in resolving environmental disputes.

When handling environmental disputes, the Indian judiciary is guided by frameworks of rights, such as Article 21 (the right to life), as well as law principles like Sustainable Development, Polluter Pays, Precautionary Principle and the Public Trust Doctrine.[82] Drawn from international and foreign environmental law, these principles have now become an integral part of Indian environmental law albeit with some definitional adaptations and conceptual adjustments. Further, the EJ discourse in India mirrored the rising judicial understanding of the link between human rights and environmental protection.[83] Ambiguity and inadequacies in environmental legislation, administrative inefficiencies, and multi-layered corruption prompted the apex court to assume the role of an environmental caretaker. In State of Uttaranchal vs B S Chaufal, the court observed;

The scale of injustice occurring on the Indian soil is catastrophic. Each day hundreds of thousands of factories are functioning without pollution control devices. Thousands of Indians go to mines and undertake hazardous work without proper safety protection. Everyday millions of litres of untreated raw effluents are dumped into our rivers and millions of tons of hazardous waste are simply dumped on the earth. The environment has become so degraded that instead of nurturing us it is poisoning us.[84]

Such an assessment of environmental deterioration and its implications for public health encouraged affected individuals, environmentalists, and NGOs to approach the judiciary, particularly the supreme court. In response to such apathy, the Supreme Court (SC) in the 1980s introduced *Public Interest Litigation* (PIL), a people-centered method that fosters access to justice via judicial practices and resolutions.[85] This opened the judicial space to previously barred people owing to caste, poverty, illiteracy, or isolation. Now people may on their own or through a court-recognized acquaintance (amicus curiae) use the law to safeguard their human rights.[86] The use of PIL has resulted in a significant change in India's environmental landscape,[87] however, inconsistency and uncertainty in accepting or rejecting environmental PILs has left the public-spirited citizens with deep concerns.
Another significant development was the apex court's distinctive interpretation of Article 21 of the Constitution of India, that reads "no person shall be
U. SIDIQUE AND K. ZAIDI

deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law.[88] It guarantees people the right to life which constitutes "the first right of man,"[89] for it provides the foundation for all other rights. Article 21 offers the legal justification for the compatibility of human rights with environmental protection. According to the Supreme Court, the term "right to life" encompasses not only physical existence but also quality of life and this has been reinterpreted in a number of judgments. In Francis Coralie Vs. Union Territory of Delhi, Justice Bhagwati stated that, "the right to life includes the right to live with human dignity and all that goes along with it, namely, the bare necessities of life."[90] Further, in other judgments like Subhash Kumar vs. State of Bihar[91] and Virender Gaur v State of Haryana, the Supreme court held that the fundamental right to life under Article 21 also includes right to healthy environment, one which is free from pollution. The court in the latter case maintained that, "it would be impossible to live with human dignity without a human and healthy environment."[92] Similar assertion was made in Chinnappa and Godavarman vs Union of India in 2002. Since then, the apex court has recognized the right to clean air, water, and a pollution-free environment as a fundamental and basic human right.

This activism of the Supreme Court, along with the proliferation of the PIL culture, has been a driving force in the quest for EJ in India. The 1984 Bhopal Gas Disaster was a turning point, as it led to stricter application of environment-related legislations and executive orders in India.[93] A distinct Ministry of Environment was founded in 1985 and subsequently renamed the Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate Change (MoEF&CC).[94] In addition, various environmental laws were drafted, such as the Environment Protection Act of 1986, along with various waste management rules like Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling) Rules, 1989. Other measures introduced included the adoption of the Environment Impact Assessment (EIA) notification in 1994 and the National Environment Appellate Authority (NEAA) in 1997 to curb the unfettered urbanization and concretization of the natural environment under the pretext of development. In light of these developments, the apex court made a number of institutional reforms to adjudicate environmental matters and safeguard the rights of marginalized communities.[95]

The higher judiciary established green benches to specifically hear environmental matters.[96] Despite differences in structure, genesis, and institutional resources, these green benches have all contributed to the development of Indian environmental jurisprudence. After the SC in a number of judgments like Indian Council for Enviro-Legal Action vs Union of India[97] and AP Pollution Control Board vs Prof M V Nayudu[98] hinted at specialized environmental courts, the Law Commission of India in 2003 recognized this need in its
186^{\text{th}}
report, "Proposal to Constitute Environment Courts," and proposed establishing up environment-specific courts.[99] Following this, the government
INDIA REVIEW

via an act established the National Green Tribunal in 2010. The Tribunal renders decisions on environmental preservation, forest and natural resource conservation, environmental rights management, and compensation for injuries to persons and property.[100] As per its statute, the NGT adheres to some best practices like open rule of standing, legislated trial and appellate jurisdiction,[101] and is also explicitly required to follow the principles of sustainable development, polluter pays principle, and the precautionary principle while rendering orders, decisions, and awards.
Since its establishment, the NGT has rendered numerous decisive verdicts with favorable environmental implications.
For instance, in Kalpavalli Tree Growers Mutually Aided Cooperative Society Ltd vs Union of India,

the NGT under Section 15(1), directed the respondent to provide a reparation of 50 lakh rupees for the environmental harm inflicted by the installation of windmills within the forest area. In the case of Satpal Singh vs Municipal Council Gardhiwala,

the tribunal issued a directive for the relocation of the dumping site away from the residential area. In a similar case, People for Transparency through Kamal Anand vs State of Punjab, the Delhi bench of the NGT proposed to implement the Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) management plan of 2014 in the state of Punjab for the larger welfare of the public.
Further, with other cases like State of Meghalaya vs All Dimasa Students Union and Ors.
against rat-hole mining in the State of Meghalaya and Vardhman Kaushik vs Union of India

against rising air pollution in the NCT of Delhi, the NGT has significantly helped in furthering environmental justice in India by changing the way people think about environmental problems and solutions. However, there are challenges like insufficient financial and administrative assistance, and limited political support, which compromise its autonomy and operational effectiveness.

Additionally, with only five branches nationwide, there are accessibility issues for economically disadvantaged individuals, as local civil courts no longer have jurisdiction in environmental cases under Article 29(1) and Article 29(2) of the NGT Act.
Discussion

This article aimed to explore how EJ originated and matured into an academic discourse to describe the development of EJ in India. It further examines whether India's current environmental rhetoric mirrors environmental justice as that in the Global North. While the countries in the global North prioritize discussions surrounding a "green" agenda of environmental preservation, biodiversity conservation, and the protection of the ozone layer, those in the South champion a "brown" agenda, which places a strong emphasis on poverty alleviation, infrastructure development, healthcare, and education.[109] These two perspectives are also characterized as the "ecological sustainability" and "environmental health" agendas, respectively.[110] Further, unlike in the West,
U. SIDIQUE AND K. ZAIDI
where environmentalism emerged as an outcome of post-material and post-industrial society, in India it developed in the early stage of the industrial process.

In the West, EJ scholarship emerged independently of and often in conflict with traditional environmental movements, while in India, environmental, social, and human rights concerns are typically interlinked. Also, environmental activism in India is typically about people's rights over natural resource use.

Despite the historical antagonism between these two streams, a new paradigm called "Just Sustainability Paradigm" integrates them.[113] It links to both the green and the brown agenda of environmental scholarship and is built on the definition of sustainability as "to ensure a better quality of life for all, now and into the future, in a just and equitable manner, whilst living within the limits of supporting ecosystems."[114] Here, justice and fairness are respected, but so is our life-supporting environment. The EJM recognizes this broad rhetoric of sustainability that does not see environment distinct from the social and political.[115] Under this approach, social justice and environmental issues are interwoven, and neglecting this relationship would exacerbate social and environmental unsustainability. It also contends that environmental sustainability cannot be confined to environmental issues alone. Social needs, welfare, and economic opportunity must be linked to environmental challenges for a society to be really sustainable.[116]

Given its history and links with the civil rights movement, as well as its experience with grassroots communities, it is unsurprising that the US experience dominates the global environmental justice discourse. This article corroborates the claim made by earlier studies[117] that many other countries have also acknowledged the linkages between environmental discrimination and social marginalization. India is currently leading the world in mapping ecological conflicts and environmental injustices on EJAtlas, a global information portal on environmental justice.[118] However, considering the diversity of its social and ecological environments, there hasn't been as many EJ studies in India. While the early studies emphasized social movements and the procedural injustices they raised,[119] only lately has research shown how socially disadvantaged and poor places in India endure disproportionate rates of hazardous waste generation[120] and particulate air pollution.[121]
Conclusion

As evident from this review, environmental justice, although originated in the heartlands of the industrialized United States, is also entrenched in the colonization and the oppression of indigenous communities worldwide. In the Indian context, Environmental justice may have recently become a recognized concept; however, as a philosophy, it has been a mainstay of Indian environmental consciousness since the 1970s. This review suggests that India has an
INDIA REVIEW

indigenous environmental justice movement, albeit not on the lines of the US, where racism has been the basis of EJ struggles. The scholars have regarded the Chipko Movement of 1973 as India's first Environmental Justice Movement. This study, however, acknowledges that the Bhopal disaster of 1984 indicates a far better starting point, considering how EJ initially developed against unfair siting of hazardous facilities.

This paper argues that the current principles and approaches characterizing Environmental justice are gaining currency in the Indian literature. This indicates that the discourse on environmental justice in India is currently shaped by both global environmental justice movements as well as indigenous efforts and concerns about environmental challenges. The growing recognition of environmental justice is quite apparent in recent works. However, theoretical inquiries in this area are inadequate, and the scholars have hardly been able to conceptualize the key concepts peculiar to the realities of the Indian milieu. The focus continues to be on empirical investigations discovering the disproportionate burdens. In order to better understand how EJ is conceptualized in India and to clear out any ambiguities in its use, further research is required. Only then could we have a meaningful theoretical framework for recognizing and evaluating environmental injustice in India.
